fields: Inhibition of Vit K epoxide reductase, affecting Factors (2,7,9,10) and Protein C&S

55M, 2hr hx of central, retrosternal, crushing chest pain on exertion.
What are his cardiac risk factors?

PDx:[[oc1:: IBD, most probably Ulcerative Colitis]]

DDx:
  • Other IBD - [[oc2::Crohn's disease]]
  • Infectious - [[oc3::Gastroenteritis (Camp., Shigella, C. Diff)]]
  • Malabsorptive - [[oc4::Coeliac disease]]
  • Medications - [[oc5::Pseudomembranous colitis, laxatives]]
  • Others, especially when older - [[oc6::Ischaemic colitis, malignancy, diverticulitis, bleeding disorder]]

State your PDx and DDx
43yo F, presents with 2wk Hx of bloody diarrhoea, 12x in last 10hrs. Pain in L and R upper quadrants, previous episode 2yrs ago that resolved.

History: 
  • [[oc1::Characterise pain and diarrhoea. 
  • Ask about extraintestinal IBD Sx (joints, eyes, skin)
  • Constitutional and infective Sx
  • PMHx, Meds, FHx, travel Hx
  • Smoking/drugs/ETOH
    • ]]
Examination:
  • [[oc5::
  • Clubbing
  • Anaemia (pallor, stomatitis, sinus tachy)
  • Abdominal palpation (tenderness, masses)
  • DRE peri-anal disease (UC), mass, fissure, haemorrhoid, frank blood
  • Extra-intestinal examination (eyes uveitis, joints sacroillitis, skin pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum
    • ]]
Bedside:
  • [[oc2::Stool MCS, OPS (ova, parasites, spores)
  • C. Diff toxin test (TcdA/TcdB)
    • ]]
Bloods:
  • [[oc3::FBC (Fe anaemia), ESR/CRP
  • LFT (liver issues, pri sclerosing cholangitis)
  • EUC/CMP (electrolyte disturbances, dehydration)
  • ANCA/ASCA (p-ANCA +ve in 70% of UC)
  • Blood cultures (sepsis)
    • ]]
Imaging:
  • [[oc4::Colonoscopy + biopsy (contraindicated with toxic megacolon)
  • AXR or CT Abdo (if suspect perforation or toxic megacolon - >6cm diameter)
    • UC - loss of haustra, granular mucosa, shortened colon
    • Crohn's - cobblestoning, "rose thorn" ulcers, colon strictures w/ rectal sparing
    ]]
Other:
  • TFT (hyperthyroid = non-bloody diarrhoea)
  • Transglutaminase Ab test + Anti-endomysial Ab (IgA type) = Coeliac disease
  • FOBT 
  • PCR (?virus)

What are the categories of complications of UC?

Intestinal (acute, chronic)

Extra-intestinal (eyes, skin, joints, haem, hepatobill, bones, dehydration, nails)
What are the acute complications of UC?

• Perforation +/- peritonitis
  • Bleeding (from erosion of an artery, rare, but life threatening)
  • Toxic megacolon +/- rupture
What are the chronic complications of UC?

• Colonic adenocarcinoma (CRC)
  • Perianal abscess
  • Fistula (more likely with Crohn's due to transmural inflammation)
  • Strictures
  • amyloidosis

Symptomatic relief: 
  • [[oc1::Antidiarrheal agents: loperamide
  • Anticholinergic medication: propantheline, dicyclomine
    • ]]
Acute: [[oc2::using 5-aminosalicylic acid derivatives (5-ASAs) 
rectal +oral +oral corticosteroids alternatives and biologicals
]] 

Maintainence: [[oc3::Oral/rectal 5-ASA  both  alternatives]]

  • [[oc2::Infliximab]]

General
  • [[oc1::nicotine]] abstinence
  • lactose intolerance - [[oc2::lactose-free diet]]
  • appropriate [[oc3::nutrion]] supplementation
  • bile acid diarrhoea - [[oc4::give ion-exchange resins to bind bile acids (eg. cholestyramine) to reduce osmotic diarhhoea (risk of steatorrhoea)]]
  • During acute episodes: [[oc5::avoid dietary fibre, consider parenteral nutrition]]

Pharmacotherapy
  • [[oc6::step up or step down therapy (weak to strong, or strong to weak meds)]]
Surgery
  • [[oc7::
  • if medical therapy fails, or complications (obstruction, fistula, stricture)
  • non-curative, last resort
  • resection of affected bowel
    • ]]
Prevention
  • [[oc8::
  • regular check ups
  • Smoking cessation
  • prophylactic Abx, 5-ASAs, etc
    • ]]

Patient presents with flank pain and dysuria.

HR: 120 bpm
BP: 90/60
What is your diagnosis?

PDx: Septic shock, secondary to pyelonephritis
given low BP, tachycardai, fever, dysuria

DDx: 
Infectious: acute cystitis, PID
Non-infectious: renal calculi

1. Primary Investigations 
[[oc1::ECG (repeated) ]]
  • Possible findings on ECG: 
    • [[oc2::Peaked T waves, ]]
    • [[oc2::ST elevation ]]
    • [[oc2::T wave inversion (24h) ]]
    • [[oc2::q waves (3d), ]]
    • [[oc2::PE]]
Troponin T & I 
  • When is the peak elevation for Troponin, and how fast does it increase? 
    • [[oc3::Peaked 12-24hr (elevated for 1 wk). Increases in 2 hr, CK increases in 6hr ]]
  • What is Troponin 
    • [[oc4::Protein that regulated calcium mediated contraction of cardiac muscle ]]
  1. Secondary Investigations (Bloods) 
[[oc5::FBC Exacerbating Anaemia or Infection (reduces O2 delivery) ]]
[[oc5::EUC Potassium levels (risk of arrhythmia), Baseline (to detect progress towards shock) ]]
[[oc5::BGL Diabetes if >11.1mmol/L (risk factor)]]
[[oc5::HbA1C >7% (indicative of diabetes) ]]
[[oc5::Lipids LDL , HDL , Total Chol , TG (risk factor statin)]]

3. Imaging 
[[oc6::CXR LVF]]
  • Signs of acute heart failure: 
    • [[oc7::Alveolar oedema]]
    • [[oc7::Kerly B lines]]
    • [[oc7::Effusion]]
  • Signs of chronic heart failure: 
    • [[oc8::Cardiomegaly,]] 
    • [[oc8::Dilated upper vessels]]
Signs of DDx 
[[oc10::TOE - LVF]]
[[oc11::Coronary angiogram Narrowed segment of a coronary artery (likely LAD) with reduced flow distal to this]]

The coronary sinus orifice (opening, also known as the ostium of the coronary sinus) is located at....?
The posterior, inferior surface of the heart, medial to the inferior vena cava opening, just superior to the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve.
What is the coronary sinus orifice guarded by?

• [[oc1::LAD (40-50%): Proximal 2cm affected. Infarct of anterior + apical + septal LV (V1-V4 anteroseptal)]]
  • [[oc2::RCA (30-40%): Proximal and distal 1/3. Infarct of posterior + inferior LV (II, III, avF inferior) ]]
  • [[oc3::Left Circumflex (15-20%): Proximal 2cm. Infarct of lateral LV (V4-V6, I, avL anterolateral) ]]

    • [[oc6::~90% mortality]]
  • [[oc7::Papillary muscles in LV acute ]]
    • [[oc8::Acute mitral incompetence CHF]]

      • Small: left-right shunt RV overload & LV output vasoconstriction worsing left-right shunt LV failure
    • {{c6::~90% mortality}}
  • ...
    • ...

    • Leads to acute cardiac tamponade cardiogenic shock death
    • ~90% mortality
  • Interventricular septum

      • Large  drop in cardiac output causing cardiogenic shock as contraction of the left ventricle will result in much blood being forced into right ventricle
      • Small: left-right shunt RV overload & LV output vasoconstriction worsing left-right shunt LV failure
    • ~90% mortality
  • {{c7::Papillary muscles in LV acute }}
    • ...

What EUC results do you get in ARF?
Significant deterioration in renal function over hours or days.
What are the clinical manifestations of ARF
Biochem findings of Acute Renal Failure
Elevated Urea and Creatinine, Elevated K+, Elevated H+

GFR = volume of fluid filtered by all glomeruli per minute (ml/min)
Why is creatinine clearance used for GFR calculations?
Creatinine is a breakdown product of muscle cells, produced at a relatively stable rate and almost completely excreted by the kidneys therefore is the easiest/cheapest way to estimate GFR
How to calculate Creatinine Clearance by 24hr urine collection
GFR = Urine Creatinine Conc. x 24hr urine volume / plasma creatinine conc.

Cockcroft Gault equation (Takes into account age, weight, gender, and serum creatinine) 
- eGFR = (140-age) x (weight in kg) x (0.85 if female) / Serum creatinine x 0.815 umol/L
What are the main stages of renal failure

Stage 1 GFR >90ml/min (Kidney damage - normal GFR) 
Stage 2 GFR = 60-89 (Kidney damage, mildly decreased GFR) 
Stage 3 GFR = 30-59 (Moderately decreased GFR) 
Stage 4 GFR = 15-29 (Severely decreased GFR) 
Stage 5 (end-stage) Renal failure if GFR <15ml/min (requires dialysis)
What is the normal range for potassium concentration?
Normal range for the potassium concentration in serum is 3.8 to 4.9 mmol/L
Where is tubular Na exchanged for Serum K
Exchange of tubular Na with serum K occurs due to effect of what?
Intracellularly: Most abundant intracellular cation in the body

1. Reduced ability to excrete K+ 
2. Reduced ability to excrete non-volatile acids, leading to acidosis, and shift of K+ out of cells to exchange with uptake of H+.

1. Peak T waves with small P waves, broad PR interval 
2. Wide QRS complex 
3. Ventricular Fibrillation 

Progresses to atrial arrest and broadened QRS complex indicating ventricular arrest 
Unusual when serum potassium concentration is lower than 7mmol/L

Potassium is mainly an intracellular ion. 
Concentration maintained by the Na/K/ATP pump 
Extracellular Potassium determines cell depolarisation and repolarisation 
HyperK+ : Shifts resting membrane closer to threshold for depolarisation 
  •  Predisposes areas to depolarise and impairs repolarisation
How does hyperK+ lead to arrhythmias?

How do you treat hyperkalaemia in RF?

1. Insulin: Insulin promotes intracellular uptake of K+ (REMEMBER DKA) 
2. Glucose: Facilitates uptake of BOTH glucose and K+ into cell 
Note: Insulin and glucose is indicated when a sodium load is contraindicated
Emergency treatment for life-threatening hyperkalaemia of any cause is to:

Give intravenous calcium gluconate (which has an immediate cardiac stabilising effect)
  • Calcium alleviates the membrane depolarisation of severe hyperkalaemia, without lowering the serum potassium concentration
Correct any volume depletion
  • Dilutes hyperkalaemia but will also increase K excretion in hypovolaemic renal failure

Interpret this muthafckn spiro. What are normal values for FEV1 and FVC? How does this affect his surgical chances?

1. Obstructive picture: FEV1/FVC < 70% 
2. FVC ~ 5-6L
   FEV1 ~3-5L
3. Chances of surgery are less given this pre-existing lung surgery which will be exacerbated given further reduction of lung volume with mode of surgery (lobectomy)

  • [[oc1::Wishes of patient: autonomy should be respected]]

Cancer factors:
  • [[oc3::Location: less likely if hilar c.f. peripheral ]]
  • [[oc4::Stage/mets: higher stage cancers may be better managed palliatively ]]
  • [[oc5::Type: affects growth rate, location and mets.]] 
  • [[oc6::Small cell lung cancer - normally only chemo.]]
  • [[oc7::Symptoms of mets: palliative surgery may be indicated]]
  • [[oc8::Hoarseness, SVC obstruction, chest pain, pleurisy.]]

PDx + DDx: 36yo woman presents to ED with tachycardia, tachypnoea, hypotension, peripheral cyanosis, silent chest with past history of asthma. Salbutamol not effective. HR 150, Hypotensive, RR 36, normal urinalysis.

1. Status asthmaticus (Acute exacerbation of asthma, unresponsive to bronchodilators) 

2. DDx
- Anaphylaxis/anaphylactic shock 
- Foreign body 
- PE 
- Tension Pneumothorax 
- Pneumonia 
- Acute Exab. of COPD 
- Upper airway obstruction (tumour)
- Triggered by URTI, allergens, weather, exercise, stress, drugs
- Severe: Hypotensive, tachycardia/pnoea, unresponsive to broncodilators: Unable to speak, confused, FEV1 < 50%, SaO2<90%, PaO2 < 60, PaCO2 > 36

Airway: 
  • [[oc1::Be aware of foreign body]]
  • [[oc2::Be ready to intubate]] 
Breathing: 
  • [[oc3::Oxygen mask (aim for SaO2 > 95%) ]]
  • [[oc4::Bronchodilation Salbutamol 100g: MDI + Spacer OR Nebulised with O2 (aim for PEFR >90% best) + Ipratropium nebulised with O2 ]]
  • [[oc5::Corticosteroids oral prednisone 25-50mg QID for 5 days, or budesonide inhaled or IV hydrocortisone]]
  • [[oc6::IV salbutamol, aminophylline and magnesium sulfate may be used in severe acute asthma unresponsive to other treatment]]
  • [[oc7::Adrenaline if still no response or arrest ]]
Circulation 
  • [[oc8::NS (normal saline) IV bolus: 20ml/kg as fast as it will run then reassess ]]
Investigation 
  • [[oc9::CXR (exclude pneumothorax) ]]
  • [[oc10::ABG ]]

Primary Investigations (LUNG FUNCTION) 
  • [[oc1::Peak Expiratory Flow Rates (PEFR) L/minute: measures maximum speed of expiration (indication of airway patency & respiratory effort ability). ]]
    • [[oc2::100-80% best = green zone = normal ]]
    • [[oc3::<80% best = yellow zone = asthma symptoms present, need for treatment. ]]
    • [[oc4::<50% best = red zone = need for treatment immediately, likely attack imminent ]]
  • Spirometry: [[oc5::Asthma shows FVC <80% pred, FEV1 <80% pred, increased RV ]]
  • [[oc6::Pre & post bronchodilator Spirometry 
    • Reversibility = >12% FEV1 increase ]]
  • [[oc7::ABG: hypoxaemia & hypercarbia in asthma, respiratory acidosis (uncompensated in this case)]]
  • Laboratory
    • [[oc8::FBC: signs of infection, eosinophilia]] 
    • [[oc9::Sputum MCS: possibly infective cause e.g. viral or bacterial, eosinophilia ]]
  • Imaging
    • [[oc10::Chest x-ray: normal, hyperinflation (COPD) or pneumonia (consolidation)]]

Primary Investigations (LUNG FUNCTION) 
  • Peak Expiratory Flow Rates (PEFR) L/minute: measures maximum speed of expiration (indication of airway patency & respiratory effort ability). 
    • 100-80% best = green zone = normal 
    • <80% best = yellow zone = asthma symptoms present, need for treatment. 
    • <50% best = red zone = need for treatment immediately, likely attack imminent 
  • Spirometry: Asthma shows FVC <80% pred, FEV1 <80% pred, increased RV 
  • {{c6::Pre & post bronchodilator Spirometry 
    • Reversibility = >12% FEV1 increase }}

How do kidneys compensate for acidosis?
Kidneys increase excretion of H+ ion so the urine becomes acidic and thereby increases the retention or reabsorption of HCO3- into the blood.
Interpret: Oxygen 75mmHg (80-100), CO2 50 mmHg (35-45), Bicarb 26 (24-32), Base Excess -6 (-3 to 3), SaO2 76%
Hypoxia, hypercapnia. Type II respiratory failure (hypercapnic). Uncompensated respiratory acidosis

[[oc1::Short acting B-adrenergic agonists (4-6hrs):]] Salbutamol and Terbutaline 
  • [[oc2::Dilate bronchial smooth muscle by direct action on B2 adrenergic receptors and inhibit the release of  inflammatory mediators by mast cells. ]]
  • SE: [[oc3::tremor and tachycardia ]]

Muscarinic receptor antagonists: [[oc4::Ipratropium Bromide]] 
  • [[oc5::Antagonises bronchial constriction caused by parasympathetic stimulation of M1 and M3 receptors when binding Ach. ]]
  • [[oc6::Onset of action is slow (30-60mins) so used in combination with B2 adrenoreceptor agonist.]] 
  • SE: [[oc7::tachycardia, nausea, vomiting, dry mouth]] 

Xanthines - [[oc8::Theophylline ]]
  • [[oc9::Inhibits phosphodiesterase (which metabolises cAMP) thus increased intracellular cAMP relax smooth muscle]] 
  • Used when [[oc10::B2 agonists ineffective ]]
  • SE: [[oc11::CNS stimulation, cardiac stimulation, nausea, anorexia ]]

What are the names of symptom controllers of asthma?
What is the mechanism of inhaled glucocorticoid? (name examples)

Fluticasone/budesonide: 

Anti-inflammatory + immunosuppressant binds to intracellular glucocorticoid receptors (dimerise and affect DNA transcription) annexin-1 (protein) (& COX-2 directly) IL and TNF = N, M and mast cells, and reduced T cell activation, proliferation and IgG production
SE:  Oral thrush and hoarseness, systemic (diabetes, osteoporosis, cushings, etc.)

Codeine, Dextromethorphan, Pholcodine 
- Should only be used if unproductive or excessive as cough removes foreign material and mucous secretions from the bronchi
What to give for acute exacerbation of asthma?
Antibiotics, O2 therapy, bronchodilators and glucocorticoids
What is the MOA of montelukast?
Leukotriene receptor antagonist: inhibits the cysteinyl LT receptor   bronchial smooth muscle contraction from LTs
What is the MOA of Sodium Cromoglycate?
inhibits release of inflammatory mediators from mast cells
S/E: cough, throat irritation, bitter taste, transient bronchospasm
What does long-term management of asthma entail?

1. Short acting Beta-agonist + inhaled corticosteroids (when a SABA is required 3 or more times a week)
- Evidence supports using SABAs on an as-needed basis rather than regularly. 
- High or increasing use of SABAs or increasing asthma symptoms indicates that asthma is poorly controlled and needs a review of treatment.
If control is not achieved (attacks twice a week), consider adding a long-acting beta2 agonist or increasing dose of inhaled corticosteroid:
for children, the latter is generally recommended
for adults, evidence supports the former, however, guidelines differ.

2. Education and review of technique

3. Establishment of acute attack action plan

• Hx: Frequency of salbutamol use 
  • Exam: 
    • Vitals RR, O2 saturation 
    • Signs & symptoms dyspnoea 
  • Ix: 
    • PEFR (peak exp flow rate) before and after salbutamol 
    • Annual spirometry
What is the treatment for COPD?
Primarily aimed at treating bronchoconstriction from neutrophil inflammatory

1. Salbutamol (Ventolin) 
[[oc1::Class: Short acting 2 agonist ]]
MOA: 
[[oc2::Stimulates 2 receptors on bronchial smooth m bronchodilation airflow resistance (wheeze) ventilation + mucus secretion + mast cell degranulation (inhibits histamine, LT, PG) ]]
S/E: [[oc3::Tachycardia/palpitations -- AF/ paroxysmal SVT (1), Tremor (2), Insomnia, Muscle cramp, K, BGL ]]

2. Budesonide (Pulmicort)/Fluticasone (Flixotide)
Class: [[oc4::Inhaled Corticosteroid (ICS) ]]
MOA: 
[[oc5::Glucocorticoid effect: regulate gene transcription neutrophil & T cell fn + COX2 airway inflammation and bronchial hyper-responsiveness ]]
S/E: [[oc6::Dysphonia, Candidiasis, Bruising, Skin irritation ]]

3. Salmeterol (Serevent) 
Class: [[oc7::Long acting 2 agonist]] 
MOA: 
[[oc8::Stimulates 2 receptors on bronchial smooth m bronchodilation airflow resistance (wheeze) ventilation + mucus secretion + mast cell degranulation (inhibits histamine, LT, PG) ]]
S/E: [[oc9::Tachycardia -- AF/ paroxysmal SVT (1), Tremor (2), Insomnia, Muscle cramp, K, BGL]] 

4. Remember Combination Inhalers: 
Symbicort = [[oc10::eformoterol + budesonide ]]
Seretide = [[oc11::salmeterol (Serevent) + fluticasone (Flixotide) ]]

Inhaled SABAs (immediately before exercise) are first-line treatment

DDx: 55 M presents after new onset seizure. Episode involved twitching and weakness of the left face and upper limb. He recently had some terrible headaches. He also experienced sensory changes and decreased memory and personality changes.

PDx: Cortical lesion in the frontal and parietal lobe, and resultant simple partial seizure (focal aware)
  • Pre- and post-central gyrus sensory and motor changes 
  • Frontal lobe (dorsolateral PFC) mood changes
Possible focal lesions include: 
  • Neoplastic causes 
    • Primary or secondary
    • Malignant or benign 
      • Most common being GBM
  • Infarct
  • Trauma (extradural, subdural, SAH)
  • Infection (e.g. abscess)
DDx 
  • Migraine with aura 
  • TIA 
  • Metabolic dysfunction: hypo/hypernatraemia
  • Psychogenic (non-epileptic seizure)
  • Syncope

Primary
  • [[oc1::CT brain without contrast: rule out haemorrhagic stroke, quicker, but radiation ]]
  • [[oc2::MRI head & brain with contrast more specific (T1,T2, FLAIR, DWI)]]
Bedside
  • [[oc3::ECG: arrhythmias, possible MI?]]
  • [[oc4::Carotid artery dopplers if ?stroke + CT or MR Angiography if ischaemic stroke]]
Laboratory
  • [[oc5::FBC: infective source (possibly brain abscess)]]
  • [[oc6::UEC: electrolyte levels]]
  • [[oc7::Coags: hypercoagulable state]]
  • [[oc8::BGL: hypoglycaemia]] 
  • [[oc9::Lipids: AS risk]]
Lumbar puncture not indicated

1. Left face and arm weakness & sensory changes
  • (DORSOLATERAL PREFRONTAL CORTEX?)
  • Lesion at l[[oc1::ateral and inferior]] portion of the [[oc2::precentral/postcentral]] gyrus ([[oc3::parietal]] lobe) 
  • This may also affect speech ([[oc4::Brocas]] area [[oc5::inferior frontal]] gyrus).
  • Mood also affected with compromise to [[oc6::frontal]] lobe and compression of [[oc7::striatum of the limbic system.]]
2. Seizure 
  • due to [[oc8::a cluster of neurons that show increased electrical activity]] repetitive and synchronized electrical response known as a [[oc9::paroxysmal depolarizing shift]]
  • The increased electrical activity of the neurons in a seizure focus can be due to a number of factors: [[oc10::altered properties of the neurons]], [[oc11::altered synaptic connections between neurons]], or [[oc12::altered conditions surrounding the neurons in their extracellular environment.  ]]
3. Headache
[[oc13:: compression and traction of pain-sensitive structures such as vessels and dura that have visceral sensory fibres]]

  • Lesion at lateral and inferior portion of the precentral/postcentral gyrus (parietal lobe) 
  • This may also affect speech (Brocas area inferior frontal gyrus).
  • Mood also affected with compromise to frontal lobe and compression of striatum of the limbic system.
2. Seizure 
  • due to a cluster of neurons that show increased electrical activity repetitive and synchronized electrical response known as a paroxysmal depolarizing shift
  • The increased electrical activity of the neurons in a seizure focus can be due to a number of factors: altered properties of the neurons, altered synaptic connections between neurons, or altered conditions surrounding the neurons in their extracellular environment.  
3. Headache
{{c13:: compression and traction of pain-sensitive structures such as vessels and dura that have visceral sensory fibres}}

Anterograde amnesia = dysfunction of [[oc2::working/short-term memory]]
  • Supplied by [[oc1::frontal]] lobe (Region: [[oc3::dorsolateral PFC]])
Other structures involved in memory
  • [[oc4::Hippocampus]] = storage of [[oc5::working memory]] long-term memory

Personality
  • Frontal lobe
    • Executive functions  [[oc8::decision making, problem solving, thought processing, consideration of culture, society and religion. ]]
    • Regulates [[oc9::emotional]] responses. 
    • Considered primary site of [[oc10::personality]]. 
  • Limbic system 
    • regulates [[oc11::emotions]] and includes the [[oc12::cingulate gyrus, nucleus accumbens, ventral tegmental area & amygdala]]

  • Patient did not lose consciousness thus seizure is [[oc2::simple]] (not [[oc3::complex]]) 
  • Seizure was [[oc4::localised]] (focused) to one area the face and upper limb i.e. not [[oc5::generalised]] involving entire body, thus seizure is [[oc6::partial ]]
  • Jacksonian seizures occur when [[oc7::a focal area of neurons discharge haphazardly producing the symptoms ]]

Astrocytes = form BBB astrocytoma/GBM (IV astrocytoma)
Oligodendrocytes = myelination oligodendroglioma
Ependymal = CSF prod Ependymoma
What is the characteristic of primary brain tumours?

1. Locally destructive
2. Rarely metastasize 
3. Dependent on CNS cells (Classified to cell type: 50% neurons, 50% glial) 
4. Adults = above tentorium cerebelli, kids = below
What tumours commonly metastasize to the brain, and how does it present?

Metastatic = Multiple, well-circumscribed @ grey-white junction
  • Lung, Breast, Kidney, skin
    • Multiple 
    • At grey-white junction

DDx:  Elderly divorced lady, heavy drinker and smoker. Found to be jaundiced, pitting oedema in LL, distended and tense abdomen, with shifting dullness. Liver not palpable, but spleen is. Bleeding haemorrhoids.

PDx: Cirrhosis of the liver secondary to EtOH 
CLD Ddx: 
Infectious: Hep C*, Hep B, Hep A/E, HIV, CMV, EBV
Autoimmune: autoimmune hepatitis, PSC, PBC
Metabolic: Wilsons, hemochromatosis, alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency
Vascular: CCF, budd-chiari syndrome 
Drugs: e.g. methotrexate 
Idiopathic: non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)*

Intrahepatic 
  • Cirrhosis Viral 
  • Viral Hepatitis 
  • Autoimmune Hepatitis 
  • Paracetamol/valproate/flucloxacillin overdose 
  • Liver Cancer 
  • Haemochromatosis 
Post-hepatic 
  • Gallstones 
  • Pancreatic Cancer 
  • Cholangiocarcinoma 
  • Autoimmune: PSC, PBC

Hydrostatic Pressure 
  • HTN 
  • Renal Failure (Na & H2O retention) 
  • Calcium channel blockers (vasodilation) 
  • Right heart failure (venous congestion) 
  • IVC compression (ovarian cancer, other tumour) 
Oncotic Pressure 
  • Liver disease (reduced protein/albumin synthesis) 
  • Nephrotic syndrome (proteinuria ! hypoalbuminaemia & oedema) 
  • Protein losing enteropathy (bacterial/parasite enteritis, Crohns) 
Vascular Permeability 
  • Infection AND/OR Inflammation
Interpret these results (in light of hepatobiliary symptoms like jaundice, LL oedema, haemorrhoids, palpable spleen)

The Liver function tests indicate: likely cirrhosis with obstruction of bile flow. 
  • AST & ALT = long standing liver parenchyma damage (too few hepatocytes left to produce these enzymes)
  • Albumin = impaired synthetic function of the liver
  • ALP & Bilirubin = Bile flow Obstructive pattern - likely due to fibrosis (cirrhosis)
  • GGT = nonspecific marker of liver or biliary disease, quite sensitive though
  • Globulin = increased circulating immunoglobulins*
The FBC shows a Pancytopaenia likely due to hypersplenism & alcoholic bone marrow suppression
Macrocytic anaemia (typical of folate/B12 def in alcoholism) 
Neutopaenia = alcoholic bone marrow suppression
Thrombocytopaenia = bone marrow suppression + hypersplenism + TPO (thrombopoietin) + bleeding
How does alcohol cause a raised GGT?

1. Gamma glutamyl transferase is an enzyme found within hepatocytes and bile duct epithelium. 

2. Alcohol is metabolised to toxic acetylaldehyde which is then converted to acetate. 
  • Excess alcohol acetylaldehyde injures hepatocytes GGT released
  • It may indicate excess alcohol consumption up to 3 or 4 weeks prior to the test.
What are the tests you can do to determine liver's synthetic function (other than LFTs)

The liver is responsible for synthesising coagulation factors, urea, and proteins 

Coags: 
PT & INR: PT has short t1/2 thus sensitive to acute and chronic disease 
aPTT 

Urea: 
Urea is synthesized by the liver from ammonium (so urea may also indicate increased ammonium concentrations encephalitis)

Protein: serum globulin and albumin
Why would people with liver disease bruise easily?

1. Hepatic failure - Reduced protein synthesis including coagulation factors, and THPO (regulates platelet production) impaired haemostasis ability. 
2. Hypersplenism - reduced platelets 
3. Alcoholism - Reduced intake of proteins, resulting in poor collagen stores, and weakened blood vessels 
4. Alcoholism - Vitamin C Deficiency, resulting in poor collagen synthesis, and impaired healing
How does alcohol and cirrhosis cause portal hypertension?

1. Alcohol a. ethanol oxidation & ROS + b. acetylaldehyde & Lipid peroxidation
2. Fibrosis of liver parenchyma 
  • MICRO: inflammation activates stellate cells to myofibroblast fn + regenerative hepatocytes. 
  • MACRO: nodular, hardened, shrunken
3. Reduced sinusoidal diameter + loss of fenestrations + central vein compressed by fibrosis   increased resistance to portal blood flow intrahepatic shunting of blood from hepatic artery to tributaries of portal vein arterial pressures imposed on portal venous system = portal HTN
How does alcohol abuse and cirrhosis lead to ankle oedema?

Ankle Oedema: 
Hepatic failure reduced hepatic protein synthesis oncotic pressure fluid leakage into interstitial spaces causing oedema (frank-starlings law)
What would be an ultimate cause of death or decompensation in cirrhosis?

Oesophageal Variceal Bleed/other GI bleed 
Hepatic Encephalopathy  
Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis & other infection
Hepatocellular Carcinoma
How can hepatic encephalopathy cause death?
Blood shunts around liver due to increased portal venous resistance  brain exposed to more ammonia  oedema  impaired neuron fn +/- ischaemia  brain death
How does Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis & other infection cause death in cirrhosis?

1. Bacteria from portal circulation bypass reticuloendothelial component of liver through shunts and reach systemic circulation 
  • Typically bacteria gains entrance through the oedematous bowel wall
2. Bacteria may exude into ascitic fluid
What is the cause of death for HCC?

Increased risk in all causes of cirrhosis (esp HCV>HBV & Haemochromatosis) 
Viral DNA integrated into genome of hepatocyte
What would a cirrhotic patient's electrolytes look like? and why??

A variety of factors can contribute to the development of hyponatremia in patients with cirrhosis. The most important factor is systemic vasodilation
  • Systemic vasodilation ADH secretion (endogenous vasoconstrictor) water retention hyponatremia
Severity of the hyponatremia is related to severity of the cirrhosis 
With more severe disease, splanchnic vasodilataon becomes more marked, resulting in a fall in mean arterial pressure and decreased renal perfusion, leading in some patients to the hepatorenal syndrome
  • Low urine output, low urinary Na+
What are the clinical signs of ascites?

Transudation of protein rich lymph into abdominal cavity in setting of portal HTN
Other contributory factors:
Hypoalbuminaemia oncotic pressure extravasation of fluid
Hyperaldosteronism due to hepatic breakdown Na & water retention

Paracentesis
  • Ascitic fluid [albumin] serum [albumin] 
    • >11 g/L difference = cirrhotic ascites 
  • The presence of an exudate suggests possible complications such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) or hepatocellular carcinoma, or that the ascites is associated with another disease process (eg malignancy, pancreatitis or tuberculosis).

Salt-reduced diet 
Spironolactone (amiloride if intolerant)
Add furosemide if ineffective
Splenic veins drains into portal vein, portal venous hypertension  splenic vein pressure hyperaemia and oedema of the spleen
What are other complications of portal hypertension?
What are the other clinical manifestations of liver disease?

Hands: Leuconychia, clubbing, palmar erythema, bruising (coagulopathy), asterixis 

Face: jaundice*, scratch marks, spider naevi, fetor hepaticus, xanthelasma 

Chest: gynaecomastia, loss of body hair, spider naevi/angioma, bruising, pectoral muscle wasting 

Abdomen: hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, portal HTN (splenomegaly, prominent chest veins,  ascites (>500mL), caput medusae, haemorrhoids, oesophageal varices, hepatic encephalopathy), testicular atrophy 

Legs: oedema, muscle wasting, bruising 
*Jaundice: typically a late sign in cirrhosis

Cirrhotic patient becomes toxic (tachycardic, hypotensive, tachypnoeic, fever)
Abdomen becomes tender. What is happening?
Patient is experiencing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, a complication of large-volume ascities in patients with severe CLD.
What is the pathophys of SBP (Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis) in the context of CLD?

• Direct transmural migration of bacteria from an intestinal or hollow organ lumen due to dysfunction of intracellular tight junctions within an oedematous bowel wall
  • Hematogenous transmission in combination with an impaired immune system. 
  • Bacteria grows rapidly in the proteinous fluid without immune response
How is SBP (spontaneous bacterial peritonitis) diagnosed?
Ascitic tap, with ascitic fluid microscopy and direct inoculation of blood culture bottles for culture.
What values in an ascitic tap for SBP are considered diagnostic?  (WCC, neutrophil count)
Total white cell count greater than 500/mm3 and/or neutrophil count greater than 250/mm3 is considered diagnostic.
Most common causative agents for SBP (Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis)?

• Enteric Gram-negative bacilli, such as Escherichia coli and Klebsiella species
  • Others Streptococcus pneumoniae, other streptococci and enterococci are encountered.
  • Anaerobes are rare

1. Before culture results available: 
  • Ceftriaxone 1 g (child: 25 mg/kg up to 1 g) IV, daily OR cefotaxime 1 g (child: 25 mg/kg up to 1 g) IV, 8-hourly 
    • Cover for gram positives and enteric gram negatives 
  • OR Tazocin  4+0.5 g (child: 100+12.5 mg/kg up to 4+0.5 g) IV, 8-hourly
2. When culture results become available, modify antibiotic therapy appropriately. Continue therapy until clinical signs of infection have resolved (usually for 5 to 10 days).

3. Patients with SBP are at risk of developing hepatorenal syndrome. IV albumin has been shown to reduce the rate of renal failure and improve survival. In association with antibiotic therapy, use:
albumin 20% 100 mL IV, once or twice daily for 3 days.
PDx 13 yo girl with increasing weakness, lethargy, complained of thirst and abdo pains. Pale, thin, drowsy, dry mucosae, ketotic factor.
Ddx for diabetic ketoacidosis symptoms? (abdo pain, ketotic fetor, thirst, ketonuria, glycosuria)

• Dehydration (vomiting, thirsty, dry mucosal membranes, tachycardic) 
  • Starvation ketosis (Hx of extremely little/nil intake. Inadequate carbohydrate availability lipolysis & ketosis to provide fuel substrate for cells) 
  • Salicylate poisoning (look for access to aspirin) 
  • Lactic acidosis (if doing heavy exercise, explains dehydration but more acute presentation) 
  • Uraemic acidosis (would need CRF, possibly if recurrent pyelonephritis)

What tests do you need to do to confirm DM?

Need 2 tests exceeding diabetic thresholds, or same test on 2 different occasions
Fasting BGL: 7.0mmol/L 
Random BGL: 11.1mmol/L 
2 hr post 75g OGTT: 11.1mmol/L 
HbA1c: 6.5% 
Symptoms of Diabetes + Random BGL 11.1mmol/L
hypovolaemia (from fluid loss in urine) concentration + renal blood flow to filter these across Bowmans membrane

•  insulin is deficit (type I diabetes), thus glucose cannot be taken up by cells 
  • glucagon gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis
Hyperglycaemia: glucose does not distribute freely between the extracellular and intracellular spaces and thus remains in the blood
Used up to neutralise acid (acetoacetic acid & -hydroxybutyric acid)  produced by ketoacidosis (compensatory mechanism)
Explain Hyperkalaemia in the context of DKA

1. acidosis & intravascular volume loss K+ shift from the intracellular to extracellular space 
2. decreased renal tubular secretion
3. insulin deficiency transport of K into cells + acidaemia H/K exchange
Explain Hyponatraemia & Hypochloraemia in the context of diabetes

Water follows osmotic gradient extracellularly towards  glucose thus [Na] & [Cl] + 
*note: Some Na will be taken up by cells when K is pushed out OR IV fluids
What kind of renal failure follows DKA?

1. BGL >13.9mmol/L + (do pin prick 1st then formal glucose) 
2. Ketones: Urine Ketouria/Ketonaemia 
3. ABG: Acidosis (pH <7.3) (metabolic) + rise in anion gap these would be performed hourly during treatment
*Note: the metabolic acidosis will be with an Increased Anion gap (Na anions, because HCO3)
4. ECG: precipitating arrhythmia or secondary electrolyte disturbance (hypo K U waves, hyper K tall T waves)
What secondary laboratory invx for DKA?

• Other Lab investigations
  • FBC (infection) 
  • CRP & ESR (inflammation) 
  • EUC (urea & creatinine due to volume depletion, Na water drawn towards extracellular glucose, K due to acidaemia H/K exchange & insulin) 
  • Lactate: (degree of hypoxaemia/hypoglycaemia) 
  • Serum osmolarity: >320mmol/kg in HHS (hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state) 
  • Blood, urine, sputum MCS: infection source 
  • HCG: prudent for any abdo pain in girl of child-bearing age 
  • Lipase & amylase: (pancreatitis)
Interpret ABG: pH 7.1, PaO2 98, PaCO2 23, Bicarb 10, Base Excess -15, O2 Sat 100
Metabolic Acidosis, with respiratory compensation (hyperventilation). Increased anion gap
Base excess = amount of base change required to bring pH back to normal.

The anion gap is the difference between primary measured cations (sodium Na+ and potassium K+) and the primary measured anions (chloride Cl- and bicarbonate HCO3-) in serum. 

Anion gap normally = 10-18mmol/L = Na (HCO3 + Cl) 

High anion gap = Metabolic acidosis

T1DM is an acquired, chronic disorder of carbohydrate, fat & protein metabolism caused by a lack of insulin from autoimmune destruction of beta cells (~90% of them) and typically requiring insulin therapy to maintain normoglycaemia
Name the 3 main factors contributing to pathogenesis of T1DM

1. Genetic susceptibility: of HLA alleles predispose to developing autoimmunity against beta  cells 
2. Environmental trigger that damages the beta cell: viral infection (enterovirus, rubella) or beta cell toxin 
3. Autoimmune reaction: develops spontaneously or triggered

1. The first presentation of someone with type 1 diabetes 
2. Change in insulin demands e.g. infection
3. skipped dose  in a diagnosed T1DM

• Insulin deficiency  
    • glucagon released
      • excess adipose breakdown FFA FFA oxidation (liver)  ketone  bodies (acetoacetic acid and -hydroxybutyric acid) ketonaemia & acidosis. 
      • hepatic & muscular glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis (+  impaired glucose uptake) hyperglycaemia & hyperosmolar state
    • intracellular glucose/osmolality
      • Osmotic diuresis (worse if insulin demand increases as there is excess glucose not being  pushed into cells but remaining in blood) Volume depletion & worsens hyperosmolarity
**End Result = ketoacidosis, hyperglycaemia, volume depletion, electrolyte imbalance
What are the Acute Complications of DKA?
What are the complications that might arise from treatment specific to DKA?

• Cerebral oedema
    • If given fast fluids, decreases serum osmolality so that it becomes < CSF osmolality leading to osmotic gradient with extravasation of fluid into the brain. 
  • Hypokalaemia (Relating to management)
    • Degree of potassium loss in the kidneys due to hyperaldolsteronism (2ndary to hypovolaemia)
    • Life-threatening when insulin given (remaining extracellular potassium shifts into cells with insulin)
  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Hypoglycaemia (excess insulin)
  • Thromboembolism (hypovolaemia)
  • Hypomagnesaemia/phosphataemia
What are the long-term MACROVASCULAR complications of diabetes?

• Large vessels (from AGE accumulation increased endothelial damage and LDL trapping by AGE (advanced-glycation end products) -modified ECM (extra-cellular matrix) accelerated atherosclerosis)
    • MI: major cause of death in diabetics 
    • CVA: stroke (lacunar/small vessel disease)
    • PVD: may result in necrosis & gangrene 
  • Immune dysfunction:
    • Reduced chemotaxis and phagocytosis impairment of cellular immunity (reduced T cell activity)
What are the long term MICROVASCULAR complications of diabetes?

• Micro Small vessels (angiopathy from AGE and sorbitol)
    • Neuropathy: Peripheral and autonomic neuropathy, Charcots joint
      • Sorbitol accumulation
  • Nephropathy: glomerulosclerosis, tubular ischaemia & interstitial fibrosis 
    • AGE cross-linking with collagen IV basement membrane thickening podocyte effacement diffuse/nodular glomerulosclerosis
    • Afferent/efferent arteriosclerosis
  • Retinopathy: non-proliferative or proliferative (neovascularisation) 
    • Glucose conversion into sorbitol within retinal cells sorbiol accumulation cell oedema oxidative stress and death
What are the Daily/Short Term monitoring steps for diabetes?

• BGL monitoring in morning (pt has not recently exercised or eaten) and also 2hrs post prandial before bed 
  • Ketones in urine when symptoms present
What are the Quarterly/Long term monitoring steps for diabetes?

• HbA1c (glycosylated Hb), glucose in body binds to Hb in blood, accurately reflects level in  last 2 wks but used for up to 3 months (even though RBC lives for 4 months) 
  • Lipids 
  • Blood pressure
  • Other autoimmune conditions: pernicious anaemia, thyroid disease, coeliac disease
  • Yearly/bianually/twice-yearly checks (vision, feet, renal)
PDx of Post-menopausal lady with fractured NOF
Name the non-modifiable factors for Osteoporosis

Female sex
Post menopause
Ageing
Late menarche
Family history of osteoporosis
Caucasian/Asian race
Short stature
Previous low-trauma fracture
Name the diseases and drugs that can cause osteoporosis

• Endocrine disorders
    • Sex hormone deficiency in men and women (PCOS)
    • Cushing syndrome
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Malabsorption syndromes
    • coeliac disease
    • gastric/bowel resection
    • bariatric surgery
  • MEDICATIONS:
    • glucocorticoids
    • excessive thyroid hormone
    • long-term heparin
    • antiepileptic drugs, particularly hepatic enzyme inducers
    • androgen deprivation therapy for prostatic cancer
    • aromatase inhibitors for breast cancer
    • thiazolidinediones for diabetes
  • Chronic medical disorders (eg liver, kidney, cardiopulmonary diseases)
  • Low body weight and weight loss, including anorexia nervosa
  • Rheumatoid arthritis and other connective tissue diseases
Name some modifiable lifestyle factors affecting osteoporosis

• smoking
  • excessive alcohol intake
  • physical inactivity
  • immobilisation
  • low calcium intake
  • vitamin D deficiency
What would you order to check bone density in someone?
Bone mineral density tested with dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA)
The number of standard deviations of their BMD at any major skeletal site compared to peak bone density (35 YO Caucasian adult) of the same sex
What value is the cut-off for osteoporosis in terms of T-score?

A person has osteoporosis when their T-score is 2.5 or lower
  • This means that a person may be diagnosed with osteoporosis before they've had any minimal trauma fractures.
What value is the cut-off for osteopenia (T-score)?
Osteopenia or low bone mass is defined as a T-score between 1 and 2.5
The number of standard deviations a person's BMD is from the age- and sex-matched mean BMD
What is the cut-off value for osteoporosis for Z-score?
When would it be better to use Z score than T score?
To assess patients younger than 50 years (more useful).
What does a low Z-score indicate?
A low Z-score (less than 2) indicates abnormal bone loss.

1. [[oc1::Hand hygiene (moment 1), check patient ID, informed consent, ensure appropriate hx and tests on blood culture request form]]
  2. [[oc2::Collect equipment (including personal protection equipment) and place on a trolley cleaned with alcohol-based wipes. Sterile gloves, small dressing pack, cotton balls, tape, tourniquet(s). Two blood culture sets (4 bottles) comprising two aerobic and two anaerobic bottles. Check expiry date for each bottle and mark 10mL above the broth for fill level.]]
  3. [[oc4::Chlorhexidine gluconate (> 0.5%) with 70% alcohol solution, opened onto the sterile field. Vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set designed to fit over the blood culture bottle (or syringe with appropriate blood transfer to vacutainer) ]]
  4. [[oc5::Remove the cap of each blood culture bottle and using a non-touch technique scrub the vial stoppers well using a fresh chlorhexidine and 70% alcohol swab and allow to dry for 30 seconds]]
  5. [[oc6::Prep and position patient appropriately, apply tourniquet to palpate and identify appropriate vein. Hand hygiene (Moment 2),  put on sterile gloves, sterilise site (dry = 30s).]] 
  6. [[oc7::Perform venepuncture using vacutainer and leash with winged infusion set/luer adapter (release tourniquet during procedure where appropriate, this will contaminate the gloved hand and using a sterile towel or the non-dominant hand is advised)]]
  7. [[oc8::Place 10mL blood per bottle (20mL/set, 40mL in total), keeping blood culture bottle upright and at/below the level of the venepuncture. Always collect/innoculate the blood culture bottles FIRST (innoculating the aerobic bottle first) then, if required, collect additional blood pathology tubes at this point]]
  8. [[oc9::Apply cotton ball and pressure to site (where possible obtain patient assistance to hold and apply pressure); repeat procedure for 2nd set of blood cultures at a different peripheral site, maintaining aseptic technique, invert bottles gently several times to prevent clotting ]]
  9. [[oc10::Discard sharps, collect all rubbish/dirty items and dispose appropriately. Label each bottle with patient name, MRN, date/time for collection of blood and location of site used for each set. Do not cover any bar codes or the bottom of the bottle and place bottles into biohazard bag and arrange to send to the lab with request form, transport bottles at room temperature. Remove gloves and perform hand hygiene (Moment 3, after the procedure). Inform px. Results not available for 48hrs]]
  10. [[oc12::Document that (a) two sets of blood cultures have been taken, (b) from which sites, (c) include reason for site choice if this differs from a peripheral site. Do not delay administering antibiotics, do not wait for results]]

Why do we use 2 sets (4 bottles) when taking blood cultures?

• A single set (2 bottles) may miss up to 40% of bacteraemias/fungaemias 
  • if only one set is taken and found +ve it could be a contaminant (false positive result). 
  • Two sets showing growth makes it easier to eliminate the risk that a skin contaminant has been cultured. 
  • Taking blood from separate sites increases the assurance of a valid sample.
Do you have to wait between taking the first and second sets of blood cultures?
No, if 2 sets of blood cultures are taken from different peripheral sites and antibiotics have not been given, there is no reason to delay between taking the blood cultures.
What is inside an aerobe (liquid culture media) bottle for blood cultures?

Liquid culture media: transport medium that provides nourishment to microorganisms to encourage their growth
  • water, carbon + energy source, source of nitrogen, trace elements, maybe growth factors
What is inside an anaerobe blood culture bottle?

low oxygen content (boiled)
nutritional substitutes (vit K, haemin)
reducing agent (eg. 1% glucose - reduces oxidation potential)

How do you monitor patients on gentamicin?

Check plasma concentrations from 1st dose (so subsequent doses can be determined) and ensuring within maximum and minimum range

This ensures:
1. Adequacy of dosing while 
2. Reducing chance of Ototoxicity & nephrotoxicity
What are the main side effects of gentamicin?

• Nephrotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity
  • Vestibular toxicty
These S/E occur more frequently in patients with prolonged exposure to serum trough concentrations of greater than 2mcg/mL and renal insufficiency. 

Despite this, in renal failure from G-ve sepsis, gentamicin as a single dose is still indicated.

What is the anatomy of the lesser omentum?

2 fold peritoneal attachment between stomach and duodenum to the liver

Originate from lesser curvature of stomach and 1st part of duodenum

Attaches on groove of ligamentum teres and surrounding portal triad

Subsection of peritoneal canivty behind the stomach. 

Anterior wall = post. wall of the lesser omentum, post viscera of stomach and ant 2 layers of greater omentum

Posterior wall = posterior 2 layers of greater omentum, transverse mesocolon, pancreas, diaphragm

the communication between the lesser and greater sac

Bounded by
Front: free border of lesser omentum
Behind: periotneum covering IVC
Above (roof): peritoneum of caudate lobe of liver
Below (floor): periotneum covering commencement of duodenum and hepatic artery
What is in the portal triad?

The term triad is a misnomer, coined before discovery of other components

Contains: 
  • proper hepatic artery
  • portal vein
  • common bile duct
  • lymphatics
  • branches of the vagus nerve

A 65 year old female who had a 10 year history of hypertension and a myocardial infarction three years previously, presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in  the left arm and leg.
 
On examination, her pulse was rapid and irregularly irregular. She had a left VII cranial nerve palsy of the upper motor neuron type and left spastic hemiparesis, with an ipsilateral upgoing plantar response

What is the lesion that caused this neurological deficit and what areas are likely to be affected?

1. R sided CVA caused by lenticulostriate artery occlusion or 
2. Haemorrhage (likely Charcot Bouchard aneurysm rupture) affecting internal capsule, basal ganglia and thalamus

A 65 year old female who had a 10 year history of hypertension and a myocardial infarction three years previously, presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in  the left arm and leg. 

On examination, her pulse was rapid and irregularly irregular. She had a left VII cranial nerve palsy of the upper motor neuron type and left spastic hemiparesis, with an ipsilateral upgoing plantar response

What are your differentials?

1. R sided MCA stroke (less likely in this case bc you would see contralateral sensory loss, cortical symptoms and a lower limb sparing)
  2. Brain tumour 
  3. Seizure with post-ictal deficit

How might this pathological process have occurred?

  1. Ischaemic stroke
    - [[oc1::cardiogenic]] embolus (Mural thrombus can be due to AF/MI)
    - [[oc2::carotid]] embolus (from atherosclerosis)

  2. Haemorrhagic stroke
    HTN --> accelerated atherosclerosis --> [[oc3::tunica media thinning]] --> [[oc4::aneurysm]] --> ruptures under HTN --> pressure oedema --> disrupts motor pathways

What is the anatomy and function of internal capsule?

The internal capsule is a [[oc1::white matter]] structure. White matter consists of myelinated and unmyelinated axons and glial cells such as [[oc2::astrocytes]], [[oc3::oligodendrocytes]], and [[oc4::microglial]] cells.

The internal capsule contains both ascending and descending axons --> carries info past the basal ganglia, separating the [[oc6::caudate nucleus]] and the [[oc7::thalamus]] from the [[oc8::putamen]] and the [[oc9::globus pallidus]]. 

The internal capsule is V-shaped when cut in a [[oc10::transverse]] plane and the bend called the genu  containing [[oc11::corticobulbar]] fibres, run between the [[oc12::cortex]] and the [[oc13::brainstem]].

  • The anterior limb is between the [[oc14::head of the caudate nucleus]] and the [[oc15::lenticular nucleus]]
  • The posterior limb is between the [[oc18::thalamus]] and [[oc19::lenticular nucleus]]
    - Contains [[oc20::corticospinal]] fibers, sensory fibers (including the [[oc21::medial lemniscus]] and the [[oc22::anterolateral system]]) from the body and a few [[oc23::corticobulbar]] fibers.

What is the function of the head of caudate nucleus?

The caudate nucleus together with the [[oc1::putamen]] makes up the [[oc2::dorsal striatum]] part of the basal ganglia

  • Motor Functions
- [[oc3::Goal-directed movements]]: Translates idea to move into actual movement, contributes to body & limb posture and speed & accuracy of directed movements
- [[oc4::Spatial mnemonic processing]]: integrates spatial information with motor behaviour formulation
  • Cognitive Functions
    - [[oc5::Memory]], [[oc6::Learning]], [[oc7::Sleep]]

The caudate nucleus together with the {{c21::putamen}} makes up the {{c21::dorsal striatum}} part of the basal ganglia

  • Motor Functions
- {{c21::Goal-directed movements}}: Translates idea to move into actual movement, contributes to body & limb posture and speed & accuracy of directed movements
- {{c21::Spatial mnemonic processing}}: integrates spatial information with motor behaviour formulation
  • Cognitive Functions
    - {{c21::Memory}}, {{c21::Learning}}, {{c21::Sleep}}

1. [[oc5::Optic radiation ]]
2. [[oc6::Wernickes area]] (Sup. temporal gyrus L temp lobe) 
3. [[oc7::Putamen and GP via lenticulostriate aa]]

What does occlusion of MCA cause?

1. contralateral hemiplegia
  2. hemisensory loss of face & arm
  3. contralateral homonymouse hemianopia (disruption to optic radiation)
  4. dysphasia (dominant)
  5. visuospatial disturbance- cannot dress, gets lost (non dominant)
What types of deficits can unilateral cerebral strokes cause?

1. Motor control
  2. Somatic sensation
  3. Vision
  4. Not hearing, bc auditory information goes to both hemispheres
What effects do you see in occlusion of PCA?

• Supplies occipital lobe
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macula sparing. If bilateral --> cortical blindness
  • Possible visual agnosia (lack of recognition or understanding of visual objects or constructs)
  • Possible alexia  (disorders of reading)
What can lesions to lenticulostriate aa (of MCA) and Heubner aa (of ACA) cause?

• Pure motor loss: paralyis of face, arm & leg on one side OR
  • Pure sensory loss: mild hemi-numbness OR
  • Mixed sensori-motor
  • Ataxic hemiparesis
What can a lesion to PICA cause?

What is the blood supply to the visual system?

  1. [[oc1::Central retinal artery]]: retina
  2. [[oc2::Ophthalmic artery]]: optic nerve ([[oc3::prox. 2/3rd]]), muscles, lacrimal duct
  3. [[oc4::ACA]]: optic chiasm and intracranial optic nerve
  4. [[oc5::Anterior choroidal artery]] (branches off the internal carotid artery): Optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus 
  5. [[oc6::Inferior branches of MCA]]: optic radiation
  6. [[oc7::Calcarine artery branch of PCA + MCA contributions]]: primary visual cortex (posterior pole of the occipital cortex)

Where is the primary visual cortex located?
On either side of the calcarine fissure of the occipital lobe, which is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery
What is the significacne of aneurysm of internal carotic to the visual system?
Internal carotid  is immediately lateral to the chiasm. Aneurysm can cause pressure on the chiasm and cause a partial, nasal hemianopia.

Describe the course and function of ophthalmic artery.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the [[oc1::internal carotid artery]] and goes along the [[oc2::optic nerve]]. It gives off a branch, the [[oc3::central retinal artery]], that penetrates the optic nerve head to spread out over [[oc4::the inner surface of the retina]].

What are the most likely causes of death in the first two weeks following lesion to the internal capsule?

  1. [[oc1::Increased ICP]]
    - [[oc2::Vasogenic and cytotoxic oedema]] --> raised ICP --> tonsillar herniation --> [[oc3::cardiorespiratory failure]]
    - [[oc4::Superimposed haemorrhage]] --> raised ICP --> herniation --> cardiorespiratory failure
  2. Secondary stroke
    - [[oc5::Basilar artery]] --> [[oc6::cardiorespiratory centre hypoperfusion]] --> death
  3. [[oc7::Hospital related causes of death]]
    - PE from immobility and hypercoagulable state 
    - Aspiration pneumonia (impaired cough reflex, hypoventilation)
    - Hospital acquired infection --> Overwhelming sepsis 
          [[oc8::UTI]] (catheter) 
          [[oc9::Staph sepsis]] (cannula)
          [[oc10::Pressure sores]] (immobility)

What is the function of the pancreas?

Exocrine - digestion

Endocrine - homeostasis of blood glucose and stomach acid
What are the exocrine excretions of the pancreas?
what are the endocrine secretions of the pancreas?
What is the venous drainage of the region of the gallbladder?

1. into hepatic veins, to IVC (gallbladder)
2. into portal vein (bile duct)
What is the lymphatic drainage of the gallbladder?

hepatic nodes (in porta hepatis)
to pyloric nodes 
to coeliac nodes
Where does the nerve supply for the gallbladder come from?
Where do the sup. mesenteric vessels lie relative to the pancreas?
Which parts of the duodenum are retroperitoneal?

2nd and 3rd

1st and 4th are intraperioneal, surrounded by peritoneum
Anatomical relations of the head of the pancreas

Anterior: tansverse colon, small intestines
Posterior: IVC, bile duct
Superior: 1st part of duodenum
Inferior: 3rd part of duodenum
Anatomical relations of the neck of the pancreas

Anterior: pylorus, lesser sac, gastroduodenal A, sup. pancreaticoduodenal A
Posterior: portal V, sup mesenteric V
Superior: splenic A
Anatomical relations of the body of the pancreas

Anterior: lesser sac, stomach, greater omentum, transv. mesocolon
Posterior: aorta, splenic V, sup. mesenteric A, L kidney, L suprarenal gland
Superior: splenic A, hepatic A, coeliac A
Anatomical relations of the tail of the pancreas

adjacent or embedded within spleen and splenic vessels
lies between the 2 layers of the ileorenal ligament
What is the arterial supply of the pancreas?

• Coeliac trunk  splenic A (neck, body tail) (arteria pancreatica magna) + superior pancreaticoduodenal A (head)
  • Superior mesenteric artery  inferior pancreaticoduodenal A (head)
What is the venous drainage of the pancreas?

Splenic vein  portal vein 
Sup pancreaticoduodenal vein  portal vein
Inferior pancreaticoduodenal vein  sup. mesenteric vein  portal vein
What is the nerve supply of the pancreas?

Parasympathetic: posterior vagal trunk and coeliac plexus (hormonal control more important than neural) 

Sympathetic: T6-10 via splanchnic nerves + coeliac plexus (postganglionic fibres run alongside blood vessels

Pain fibres: accompany sympathetic supply, T6-10 dermatome

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What is your provisional dx?

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What are your differentials?

  • Infection
- STI [[oc1::urethritis]] or [[oc2::PID]] (chlamydia, gonorrhea)
- [[oc3::Vaginitis]] (vaginal discharge, itch, burning) 
  • Non-infectious
- [[oc4::Non-infectious urethritis]] (from mechanical irritation) 
- [[oc5::Over-active bladder]] (urgency, frequency, nil UTI) 
- [[oc6::Urothelial carcinoma]] 
- [[oc7::Urolithiasis]]

- {{c21::Over-active bladder}} (urgency, frequency, nil UTI) 
- {{c21::Urothelial carcinoma}} 
- {{c21::Urolithiasis}}

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What laboratory tests would you like to do?

  • [[oc1::MIDSTREAM Urine dipstick]]: nitrites ++, leukocytes ++  (will also tell you glucose, ketones, protein, etc.)
If +ve for nitrites and leukocytes then treat empirically. If ve then consider these: 
  • URINE MCS 
- [[oc2::Microscopy and gram staining]] --> leukocytes and or bacteria (93% sensitive and 95% specific when positive)
- [[oc3::Culture & Sensitivity]]: diagnosed at [[oc4::> 10^8 CFU/L]] 
- EUC: check renal function 
- FBC, CRP, Blood cultures: if systemically unwell 
- [[oc5::Vaginal swab]] ?STI

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What imaging would you like to do? (only in men, children, UTI, non-responsive, pyelonephritis/haematuria)

• Bladder Ultrasound: stone, tumour. 
  • Renal US & KUB X-ray 
  • Cystoscopy: if no answers still
What contaminants could you find in an MSU?

• Normal skin or vaginal flora 
  • E. Coli
  • Squamous epithelial cells 
  • Staph saprophyticus

How would you do a MSU?

1. Wash hands & urethra + surrounding skin [[oc1::in normal SALINE]]
2. Begin urination (do not collect [[oc2::first urine passed 20-30mL]]) 
3. Collect urine midway through which is less likely to be contaminated 
4. Tightly cap container 
5. Wash hands 
6. Label container 
7. [[oc3::Take to lab as quickly as possible]] (reduce time allowed for further growth of organisms or alternatively, store at 4 degrees)

What can you find on a MSU dipstick?
protein, blood, albumin, glucose, ketones, leucocytes, nitrites, bilirubin, spec gravity, pH
What can you find on a MSU microscopy?
leucocytes, epithelial cells, red cells, bacteria, casts and crystals
What would you find on urinalysis if there is a UTI?
Which would you most likely see on urine microscopy if there is a UTI?
What organisms would you likely find on a gram stain if there is a UTI?

• gram ve rods = e. coli, klebsiella, enterobacteria, pseudomonas
  • gram +ve cocci = staphylococcus saphrophyticus, enterococcus
What are the most common organisms for UTI?

1. E. Coli 70-95% (Gram -ve bacillus aerobic and facultative anaerobe)
2. Staph saprophytics 5-20% (gram +ve cocci facultative anaerobe)
3. Proteus mirabilis ~1% (gram -ve facultative anaerobe)
4. Other G-ve: klebsiella, pseudonomas aeruginosa, enterobacter
5. Other G+ve: eneterococcus, staph epidermidis

  3. [[oc3::(Augmentin) Amoxycillin + clavulanate 500mg+125mg PO BD 5/7]]
  4. [[oc4::Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BD 5.7]]

If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temperature, what would happen?
Organisms collected would grow by itself leading to falsely elevated bacterial counts
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temp, what organisms can grow?

• Causative pathogen 
  • Commensals/natural flora (staph epidermidis, staph aureus, strep pyogenes)
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temp, how would this affect the results?

• May give a false +ve if a large increase in a pathogenic organisms level was found 
  • May deem result useless as contaminated if commensals overgrow
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temperature and the patient has been in hospital for 2 weeks catheterised, what organisms would grow?

How do we test for sensitivity of abx
  • CDS system = [[oc1::Calibration-Dichotomous-Susceptibility]] 
  • Organism is cultured on agar plates containing discs [[oc2::impregnated with different antibiotics]]. 
  • A [[oc3::zone of inhibition]] is seen around those antibiotics the micro-organism is sensitive to 
  • Zone of inhibition = area where no colonies are seen around the antibiotic impregnated disc. [[oc4::6mm annulus radius for most antibiotics, 2mm if vancomycin]] 
  • The disc itself is 6mm too, so basically a zone with an 18mm diameter must be found to say the micro-organism is susceptible.

Patient presents with a bee sting. Had been stung before but had only a mild response. 
Now presents with tachycardia, tachypnoea, pale, drowsy, angioedema and insp and exp stridor

What is your clinical dx?
Anaphylactic Shock (hypotensive, tachycardic, swollen tongue and urticaria) a type of distributive shock

Patient presents with a bee sting. Had been stung before but had only a mild response. 
Now presents with tachycardia, tachypnoea, pale, drowsy, angioedema and insp and exp stridor

What are your differentials?

Life Threatening
  • Status asthmaticus (atopic, stridor, tachypnoea) 
  • Other forms of shock (Cardiogenic, Obstructive, Hypovolaemic, Distributive) 
Non-life threatening (consider if patient not in shock): 
  • Urticaria/angio-oedema medications 
  • Asthma 
  • Hyperventilation/panic attack

What would the emergency management for anaphylactic shock be?

Secure Airway: 
  1. Check for [[oc1::foreign body]]
  2. [[oc2::Intubate]] if necessary (airway oedema, trauma, altered respiration)
Check Breathing: 
  1. [[oc3::High flow O2 (>10L/min)]], elevate head of bed 
Provide Circulation support: 
  1. [[oc4::Raise legs above heart]]
  2. [[oc5::2 large bore cannula IV access]]
  3. [[oc6::Bolus]] 
  4. [[oc7::Give adrenaline IM 0.5mg]] (0.5mL of 1:1000) OR if no pulse [[oc8::IV 1mL of 1:10,000]]

What difference in function is there between giving adrenaline vs noradrenaline?

• Adrenaline (more affinity for receptors --> bronchodilation) vs.
  • Noradrenaline (more affinity for receptors --> vasoconstriction - use NorAd in septic shock)
How would you manage persistent hypotension in the context of anaphylactic shock?

1. Normal saline (max 50mL/kg)
  2. If cardiogenic cause- IV glucagon bolus 1-2mg
How would you manage upper airway obstruction in the context of anaphylactic shock?
How would you manage persistent wheeze in the context of anaphylactic shock?

1. Bronchodilators (salbutamol 8-12 puffs using spacer 100mcg, or 5mg salbutamol nebuliser)
  2. Oral prednisolone (1mg/kg, max 50mg)

What investigations would you do for anaphylactic shock?

  • Clinical dx
Bedside
  • [[oc1::ECG]] must do before adrenaline, AMI 
  • [[oc2::Pulse oximetry]] 
Basics
  • [[oc3::ABG]] mixed respiratory & metabolic acidosis 
  • [[oc4::FBC]] eosinophilia 
  • [[oc5::EUC]] renal impairment from shock & K levels in case of arrhythmia
Allergy-Specific
  • [[oc6::Serum tryptase (from mast cells)]] elevated 1-3 hrs post anaphylaxis 
  • [[oc7::RAST radioallergosorbent test]] (measures allergen specific IgE in serum): >0.35 IU/L to inciting antigens 
  • [[oc8::Skin test:]] >3mm diameter wheal (good to exclude food allergy) 
  • [[oc9::Challenge test]]
Imaging
  • CXR: exclude CHF, radio-opaque foreign body, pneumonia

Interpret this ABG:
pH 7.24 (lo)
PaO2 52 (lo)
PaCO2 (hi)
Bicarb 18 (lo)
Base excess -6 (lo)
O2 sat (lo)

  • Shows mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis (low pH) 
  • High PaCO2 = [[oc1::pharyngeal & laryngeal oedema]] --> airway obstruction --> [[oc2::inability to blow off CO2]]. This CO2 + H2O --> [[oc3::H2CO3]] --> acidosis. 
  • PaO2 and O2 Sat = [[oc4::bronchiolar constriction]] impairs O2 exchange & low lung perfusion causes reduced gas exchange 
  • Low O2 = [[oc5::anaerobic metabolism]]--> [[oc6::lactic acidosis]] (anion gap should be [[oc7::]]) which uses up [[oc8::HCO3]] --> [[oc9:: HCO3 ]]

Provide pathophysiology behind clinical manifestations of anaphylactic shock
  • Inflammation
    - [[oc1::IgE-sensitized mast cells]] from prev. exposure causes degranulation and release of [[oc2::histamine]], [[oc3::tryptase]], [[oc4::PGD2]] and [[oc5::LTD4]] as well as chemotactic factors which all contribute to eventual [[oc6::leukocyte recruitment]] 
  • Bronchoconstriction
    - Tachypnoea and stridor [[oc7::SMC contraction and laryngeal oedema]]
    - Wheeze and rhonchi [[oc8::bronchospasm and mucous secretion]]
  • Urticaria and angioedema
    - [[oc9::Vasodilation and increased vascular permeability]]
  • Hypotension with associated poor end organ perfusion (pale, drowsy, incoherent + tachycardia)
    - [[oc10::Vasodilation and extravasation of fluid]]

Explain why patient has reacted with anaphylaxis only now and not previously

Allergic hypersensitivity (type 1) 
  • Mediated by [[oc1::IgE]] antibodies formed in response to a particular allergen/antigen. Bound to [[oc2::mast cells and basophils]]. In sensitised individuals, they respond by [[oc3::synthesising large amounts of IgE to an allergen]].
First exposure to allergen 
  • [[oc4::Dendritic cells]] take up allergen --> present to [[oc5::T cells]] --> differentiate into [[oc6::TH2 cells]] --> TH2 cells stimulate [[oc7::B cells into plasma cells]] --> [[oc8::making IgE]] --> IgE binds to [[oc9::FC component on mast cells]] (arming them) 
(only happens in susceptible people)

Later exposure to allergen (Anaphylaxis) 
  • Binds to IgE on mast cells --> [[oc10::crosslinks IgE]] --> mast cell degranulation 
  • 1 Mediator release (Initial maximal at 15mins post exposure)
    - [[oc11::Histamine+ LTD4]]  --> [[oc12:: Vascular permeability, Vasodilation, Bronchoconstriction, Mucus]] 
    - Adenosine --> [[oc14::bronchoconstriction]] 
    - [[oc15::Tryptase]] --> [[oc16::inflammation and chemotactic factors]] for neutrophils & eosinophils

2 Mediator release (Late-phase appears at 6hours persists for<72hrs) 
  • [[oc17::Phospholipase A2]] --> AA --> [[oc18::PG (bronchospasm)]] & [[oc19::LT (vascular permeability & bronchoconstriction)]] 
  • [[oc20::PAF]] --> platelet aggregation, histamine release & bronchospasm 
  • Mast-cell cytokines [[oc21::(TNF, IL-1, 4 ,5 ,6)]] --> recruit other inflammatory cells

Explain the mechanism of adrenaline
  1. Downregulates [[oc1::inflammatory mediator release]] from mast cells (i.e. histamine, tryptase) --> reduces [[oc2::urticaria, angioedema]] 
  2. 1/2 agonist [[oc3::vascular smooth m contraction]] --> [[oc4::peripheral vasoconstriction]] --> [[oc5::peripheral vascular resistance]] & [[oc6::oedema leakage]] --> [[oc7::BP]] + [[oc8::mucosal oedema]] 
  3. [[oc9::2 agonist]] bronchodilation 
  4. 1 agonist [[oc10::+ve chronotropic (HR)]] and [[oc11::+ve inotropic (force of contraction)]] --> [[oc12::BP]]

46F presents for a routine Pap smear. She has been experiencing intermenstrual and post-coital bleeding. 
On speculum exam she has an ulcerated lesion on the cervix. Rest of the vaginal exam appears normal

What is your provisional dx?

46F presents for a routine Pap smear. She has been experiencing intermenstrual and post-coital bleeding. 
On speculum exam she has an ulcerated lesion on the cervix. Rest of the vaginal exam appears normal

What are your differential diagnoses?

Other neoplastic
  • Endometrial/vaginal ca
  • Cervical fibroids (leiomyoma)
  • Cervical endometrial polyp
Pre-malignant
  • CIN (cervical intra-epithelial neoplasia)
  • Cervical adenocarcinoma-in-situ
Infection
  • Cervicitis infectious (HPV) 
  • PID (chlamydia obligate intracellular, gonorrhoea GN cocci)
Benign
  • Nabothian cyst may be ruptured (cyst on cervix)
  • Endometriosis 
  • Cervical Ectropion usually in pregnancy or younger women (endocervical protrusion)
What primary investigations would you do for cervical ca?

1. Speculum exam with Papanicolau test: cytobrush with endocervical and endometrial sampling  
  2. Colposcopy: for more definitive diagnosis  
    - Acetic acid staining of dyskaryotic cells --> Cone Biopsy
What laboratory investigations would you perform for cervical ca?

1. FBC: WCC (cervicitis), Hb low if excess bleeding from endometriosis 
  2. EUC & LFT: metastatic disease if suspicious of cervical cancer 
  3. Coagulation studies
  4. [HPV testing]
What imaging would you do for cervical ca?

• Transvaginal Ultrasound: allows good visualisation of cervix, uterus, ovaries and fallopian tubes to evaluate for tumours and cysts 
    - Pelvic U/S can be performed if TVUS did not visualise structures sufficiently 
  • CXR screen for metastasis
  • Staging imaging full body CT, PET, bone scan
What is the pathogenesis of cervical ca?

• HPV detected in 85-90% of precancerous lesions and invasive neoplasms
  • High-risk types = 16 [SCC] and 18 [adenoca]
  • Integrate DNA into genome of epithelial cells --> blocks TSGs P53 --> uncontrolled cellular proliferation
What types of pre-cancerous development can you get prior to cervical ca?

• CIN I, II and III (carcinoma in situ)
    - II and III = high grade requiring further colposcopy and diagnostic biospy
  • SIL (Squamous intra-epithelial lesion)

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. [[oc1::HPV transmission via microabrasions]]
  2. [[oc2::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)]]
  3. [[oc3::Viral persistence + precancerous lesion]]
  4. [[oc4::Basement membrane invasion]]

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. {{c1::HPV transmission via microabrasions}}
  2. ...
  3. ...
  4. ...

  1. HPV transmission via microabrasions
  2. {{c2::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)}}
  3. ...
  4. ...

4 stages of HPV transmission?

  1. {{c21::HPV transmission via microabrasions}}
  2. {{c21::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)}}
  3. {{c21::Viral persistence + precancerous lesion}}
  4. {{c21::Basement membrane invasion}}
What prevention measure is there for cervical ca?

• HPV vaccine covering types 6,11,16 and 18
  • Given to women aged between 9-26 as a 3 part course
    - 0,2 and 6 months
What screening measures are in place for cervical ca and consider pros/cons?

• HPV screening for sexually active women 25-74YO every 5 years if low risk & first time 2 years after last normal pap 
Pros
  • Slow progression from CIN to invasive so therefore effective as a form of prevention (may even be 10-20 years)
  • Cervical cancer drop by 70-90% since intro
Cons
  • Cytology does not give clear structure of tissue

42 year old woman who discovered a hard non-tender breast lump 15mm in diameter, cousin had breast cancer

What is your provisional dx?

42 year old woman who discovered a hard non-tender breast lump 15mm in diameter, cousin had breast cancer

What are your differential diagnoses?

Non-malignant
  1. Cystic/fibrocystic change (pain during luteal phase)
  2. Fat necrosis (hx of trauma)
  3. Breast Abscess or mastitis
  4. Lipoma
Malignant non-invasive
  1. DCIS
  2. Pagets disease (extension of DCIS into lactiferous ducts and areola)
  3. LCIS
Malignant  - Invasive
  1. Invasive ductal cell carcinoma
  2. Invasive lobular cell carcinoma
  3. Medullary carcinoma
  4. Colloid/mucoid carcinoma
What further hx would arouse suspicion of breast ca?

1. Size change: gradual increase = cancer, fluctuating = fibrocystic change 
  2. Axillary Lymphadenopathy 
  3. Systemic features (weight loss, night sweats, setc.) and signs of metastases (lung, bone, liver)
  4. Prev hx 
  5. Family hx 1, genetic (BRCA )
What exam findings would arouse further suspicion of breast ca?

• Systemic signs --> cachexia
  • Mets screen- peripheries (lymphadenopathy), bony tenderness, hepatomegaly, resp (cough/pneumonia)
Breast 
  1. Overlying skin changes (erythema, peau dorange skin dimpling)
  2. Nipple inversion, discharge and signs of pargets
  3. Palpation (fixed/mobile, hardness, tenderness, irregularity)
  4. Hard, irregular, non-tender = malignant
  5. Well-circumscribed, mobile, rubbery = fibroadenoma
Significance of family hx and breast ca?

1. A 1o Relative with unilateral Breast Ca = 2.0x RR increase 
  2. A 1o Relative with bilateral Breast Ca = 5.0x RR increase 
  3. Family hx of ovarian ca = 5.0x RR increase

List other risk factors for breast ca
  • Related pathology
    - [[oc1::LCIS or DCIS]] = 7-12x RR 
    Past history = 5.0x RR 
  • Family hx of [[oc2::ovarian cancer]] = 5.0x RR 
  • Age [[oc3::>50]] = 4.0x RR 
  • [[oc4::BRCA1/2 (AD - tumour suppressor genes) +ve]] = 4.0x RR 
  • [[oc5::High oestrogen exposure]] 
  • [[oc6::Smoking]] = 1.5x RR

What are some causes of increased estrogen exposure?

• Nulliparous = 3.0x RR 
  • First live birth >35 = 1.9x RR 
  • Overweight/obese = 1.5x RR 
  • Late menopause = 1.5x RR 
  • OCP = 1.2x RR increase

Dx for breast ca requires Triple Assessment
  1. Clinical examination Lump and nodes 
  2. Imaging (U/S <35, mammography+ US >35) 
  3. Biopsy for Cytology/histology
When do you use U/S vs mammogram?

• <35y = US only, mammogram useless as breast tissue too dense 
  • >50y = mammogram +/- US as breast is less dense (more adipose, less ligaments & ducts by %)

Does fibrocystic change predispose to carcinoma?

Benign breast lesions can be classified histologically into three categories: 
  1. Non-proliferative e.g. [[oc1::breast micro/macro cyst]], [[oc2::stromal fibrosis]]
    - Exaggerated response of normal breast changes that occurs in menstrual  cycle
    - [[oc3::Confers negligible increased risk]] of carcinoma 
  2. Proliferative e.g. [[oc4::Epithelial hyperplasia]], [[oc5::sclerosing adenosis]] (glandular aggregation and fibrous overgrowth)
    - Small increased risk of developing breast cancer = [[oc6::1.5-2.5x]]
  3. Atypical lobular hyperplasia = x5 risk

What cancer factors determine bresat ca prognosis?

Grade 
  • Degree of differentiation
  • Mitoses/tubule formation
Stage
  • Tumor (size, lobular/ductal, invasive/in situ)
  • Nodes
  • Mets
  • HER-2 Receptor 
  • Estrogen/progesterone receptor
What patient factors determine breast ca prognosis?
Discuss features of breast cancer pot

Macroscopic
  • White/pale lesion centrally
  • Hard on palpation
  • Some degree of retraction
Microscopic
  • Heterogenous tubule formation 
  • Invasion into adipose tissue
  • Peri-tumour fibrosis

1. [[oc1::Call 000, check for dangers]]
  2. Technique[[oc2::- assume SCI
    • maintain neutral position - supine, no rolling or bending
    • Do not reduce obvious deformities
    • Log-roll if necessary (eg. vomiting, bleeding, suffocation)]]
  3.  C-spine [[oc3::immobilisation
    • Semi-rigid collar (prevent further movement and SCI)
    • Place heavy rolled-up towels on both sides of neck, or hold neck to prevent movement. Reassure person
    • Place on backboard to keep spine alignment]]
  4. If [[oc4::no signs of breathing/circulaiton, commence CPR without head-tilt, just jaw thrust]]

1. [[oc1::airway obstruction. Intubate if impending respiratory distress. Surgical airway if laryngeal injury]]
  2. [[oc2::Consider haemothorax or pneumothorax.
    • Low cervical injury = paradoxical breathing (inward movement of abdo as chest expands due to loss of phrenic nerve)]]
  3. [[oc3::Control bleeding. Fluid resus w/ IV access
    • neurogenic shock vs hypovolaemic shock = loss of sympathetic tone throughout body - mass vasodilation]]
  4. [[oc4::Neurological deficits - weakness, numbness. Complete vs incomplete SCI - based on presence of anal tone]]
  5. [[oc5::Check neck is concealed by cervical collar. Once stable, evaluate if surgical referral is required]]

What landmarks can you identify on imaging at each level of the Cervical spine?

C1: {{c21::Hard palate + anterior arch of atlas}}
C2-3: {{c21::lower borders of mandible}}
C3: {{c21::Hyoid bone}}
C4-6: {{c21::Thyroid cartillage }}
C6: {{c21::Cricoid cartillage}}
C6-T5: {{c21::Trachea}}
What lesion do you see?
C6/7 dislocation w/ associated fracture and bilateral dislocated facets.
What provides stability to the cervical spine?
2 vertical columns: anterior and posterior columns
What are the components of the anterior column of the cervical spine?

• Vertebral bodies
  • disc spaces
  • Ant + Pos longitudinal ligaments
  • intervertebral discs (annulus fibrosus)
What are the components of the posterior column of the cervical spine?

• pedicles
  • facets
  • apophyseal joints
  • lamina
  • spinous process
  • posterior ligament complex
What differentiates a stable and unstable Cervical Spine Injury?

If one column is intact, the injury is stable
If both columns are disrupted, the injury is unstable

 Stable

    The structural stability of the spine remains intact.
    No neurologic deficits

Unstable

    The structural stability of the spine is compromised.
    The spine can move as two or more independent units, which may cause spinal cord injury.
What are radiographic features of unstable subluxtion injury of the cervical spine?

1. anterior subluxation >4mm
  2. Associated compression fracture of >25% of vertebral body
  3. Increase/Decrease of disc space
  4. Fanning of the interspinous distance
Do spinal nerves emerge above or below the level of the vertebrae?

From C1 to C7: above the associated vertebrae
C8: below C7
T1 onwards: below the associated vertebrae

Flexion Teardrop Fracture

from hyperflexion. Can cause ant. cervical cord syndrome due to displacement of post. vertebral body onto spinal cord

C2,3,4: [[oc1::
  • Death - respiratory failure
  • C4 - loss of all upper limb function except scapula elevation (trapezius via CN XI)]]
C5: [[oc2::
  • Some respiratory impairment (weakness of diaphragm)
  • Biceps + Brachioradialis reflex lost (C5/6) 
  • Loss of upper limb function]]
C6: [[oc3::
  • LMN weakness of shoulder abduction, adduction, elbow flexion, wrist extension (C5/6) and UMN weakness for all muscles supplied below C6
  • bowel + bladder incontinence
  • parasthesiae in C6 dermatomes and below]]
C7+T1: [[oc4::
  • Gross arm+forearm function retained
  • Impaired hand function - small muscles of hand (C7, C8, T1)
  • Loss of triceps reflex (C7/8)
  • UMN hyper-reflexia below this level
  • Loss of sensation from little finger to medial arm + forearm to axilla (C7-T1 dermatome)]]
L1/L2:  [[oc5::
  • LMN weakness below this level (formation of cauda equina @ this level) (motor neurons for spinal levels below L1/2 synapse at L1/2)]]
